title: 109_hr2793
content: The Act may be cited as the "HIPAA Recreational Injury Technical Correction Act" and includes coverage amendments. The "HIPAA Recreational Injury Technical Correction Act" amends ERISA to prohibit denial of benefits for injury treatment related to motorcycle use under group health plans. The plan allows the use of recreational vehicles like motorcycles, snowmobiles, or horseback riding, but excludes coverage for injuries if it is illegal. It does not affect insurance policies. The Public Health Service Act is amended to limit denial of benefits for treatment of injuries sustained while using specified modes of transportation like motorcycles, snowmobiles, or ATVs. This amendment ensures coverage cannot be denied solely based on the mode of transportation used. The Public Health Service Act is amended to limit denial of benefits for injuries sustained while using recreational vehicles or horseback riding. This ensures coverage cannot be denied based on the mode of transportation used. Internal Revenue Code Section 9802(a)(3) is also amended. The Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a limitation on denial of benefits for injuries sustained while using recreational vehicles or horseback riding. This ensures that a group health plan cannot deny benefits for treatment of an injury solely based on the mode of transportation used. The Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to prevent group health plans from denying coverage for injuries sustained while using certain modes of transportation, regardless of legality. The amendments also clarify insurance and reimbursement rights. These changes apply to injuries occurring after 90 days from the enactment of the Act.
